awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Aerosols, Nitrogen Oxides, and Ozone at the Mt. Bachelor Observatory
awd_abstract_narration:
This project supports the continuation of atmospheric measurements at Mt. Bachelor Observatory (MBO) in Central Oregon.  The MBO is a high elevation (2.8 km above sea level) observatory that has been utilized for atmospheric chemistry research for the past 15 years.  This project will build on the extensive knowledge base of past observations from MBO to examine key controls on western U.S. air quality in the spring, when natural and international anthropogenic sources of O3 and aerosols dominate, and summer, when wildfire smoke is a major driver of regional air pollution. 

Continuous measurements will be made at MBO of O3, CO, CO2, aerosol mass, scattering and absorption coefficients and meteorology.  Three specific hypotheses will be addressed in this research: (1) Daily variations in baseline O3 are driven by large scale dynamics and transport including the El Nino-Southern Oscillation, the Pacific Decadal Oscillation, and the changing climate. The variations in O3 that can be observed in data from both MBO and the TEMPO satellite and are important for downwind air quality in the western U.S.  (2) Nitrogen oxide chemistry in biomass burning plumes is controlled by both initial emissions and chemical processing enroute.  Production of nitrous acid from aerosol nitrates (organic and inorganic) is an important NOx recycling mechanism and a source of hydroxyl radical.  (3) Aerosol properties depend on chemical composition and aging. Light absorption by brown carbon can be comparable or exceed absorption by black carbon and can be linked to specific chemical components or chromophores. Organic aerosol volatility decreases with aging and oxidation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Thank you for reading our project report!

 The Mt. Bachelor Observatory is located on the summit of Mt. Bachelor (43.9775° N 121.6861° W; 2763) in central Oregon at 2.8 km above sea level.   The observatory is located on the summit of Mt. Bachelor, which is an isolated stratovolcano.    We operate in cooperation with the Mt. Bachelor ski area.  It is the nation's only high elevation atmospheric chemistry observatory on the west coast of the U.S.  MBO has been in operation as an atmospheric chemistry observatory since 2004.   Given that the dominant wind flow in the northern hemisphere is west to east the atmospheric pollutants we observe at the MBO become the background air that then arrives to much of the rest of the continental U.S.   The primary goals of this project were to understand sources and chemistry of O3 and particulate matter (PM) in the background air that arrives at MBO.   Both O3 and PM are important air pollutants that cause a variety of health effects at many locations in the U.S. and around the world.   From our past work we know that three sources dominate the budgets of O3 and PM at MBO: 

 1. Long range transport of pollutants from Asia.

 2. Smoke from Asia and domestic wildfires.

3. O3 from the upper troposphere/lower stratosphere.

 The goals of this project were to understand these sources better, especially the chemical processing of these pollutants, their sources and fates in the atmosphere. 

Over the time of this award, we have made near continuous measurements of these key air pollutants (O3 and PM), plus numerous other compounds that help us understand the fate of O3 and PM.  This includes nitrogen oxides, carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, hydrocarbons and other trace gases.  In particulate the 2019 experiment was the most extensive experiment we have ever conducted at this location, with a suite of mass spectrometers and other advanced research instruments.  This is especially challenging to do at a high elevation mountain observatory.  

Over the time of this award, we have analyzed the data and used it to publish 8 peer reviewed journal articles.  Some of the most important findings are:

  1. 1. Significant differences in the aerosol composition of regional vs long-range transported smoke (May et al 2023).
  2. 2. Significant differences in the aerosol amounts from prescribed fires vs wildfires in the Pacific Northwest (Marsavin et al 2023).
  3. 3. Developing of machine learning models to predict background O3 at MBO (Ninneman et al 2022).
  4. 4. Aging and significant difference in composition between aerosols observed at the surface compared to at high elevations (Farley et al 2022 and Zhou et al 2019).
  5. 5. A recent decline in the amount of O3 coming from Asia, due to emission controls there, but an increase in O3 coming from wildfire smoke in the past 5 years (Johnson et al 2023-in review).
  6. 6. Better understanding of instrumentation for measurements of O3 and PM (Bernays et al 2022 and Laing et al 2019). 

Broader impacts for this award include:

  1. 1. Availability of long-term observatory data for other scientific studies.
  2. 2. Strong involvement of early career scientists including post-doctoral fellows, graduate students and undergraduates.
  3. 3. Integration of MBO data into classroom projects at multiple universities.
  4. 4. Development of modules on climate and air quality for middle and high school level students  

 For more information on the MBO, including pictures, a full publication list and access to all archived MBO data see:

 https://sites.uw.edu/jaffe-group/mt-bachelor-observatory/

For classroom modules on climate and air quality, see:

https://sciencenorthwest.com/
